feed.title: Current watches, warnings, and advisories for United States land zones

entry.title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued September 1 at 3:33PM EDT until September 1 at 4:15PM EDT by NWS Raleigh NC
entry.summary:
SVRRAH
The National Weather Service in Raleigh has issued a
* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for... Northwestern Nash County in central North Carolina... Northeastern Wake County in central North Carolina... Franklin County in central North Carolina...
* Until 415 PM EDT.
* At 333 PM EDT, a severe thunderstorm was located near Wake Forest, or 11 miles southwest of Louisburg, moving east at 20 mph.
HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Expect damage to roofs, siding, and trees.
* Locations impacted include... Louisburg, Wake Forest, Bunn, Rolesville, Spring Hope, Youngsville, Castalia, Centerville, Pilot, and Purnell.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Franklin, NC; Nash, NC; Wake, NC

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued September 1 at 3:33PM EDT by NWS Blacksburg VA
entry.summary:
At 333 PM EDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm near Broadford, or near Chilhowie, moving east at 20 mph.
HAZARD...Wind gusts up to 40 mph and pea size hail.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects. Minor hail damage to vegetation is possible.
Locations impacted include... Marion... Saltville... Chilhowie... Mount Rogers National Recreation Area... Sugar Grove... Nebo... and Hungry Mother State Park.

cap:parameter.value: A STRONG THUNDERSTORM WILL IMPACT SMYTH COUNTY THROUGH 400 PM EDT

entry.summary:
At 330 PM EDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm near Sanford. This thunderstorm was nearly stationary.
HAZARD...Wind gusts up to 40 mph.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects.
Locations impacted include... Deltona, Sanford, Lake Mary, Orange City, and DeBary.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Inland Volusia; Northern Lake County; Seminole

cap:parameter.value: A STRONG THUNDERSTORM WILL IMPACT NORTHWESTERN SEMINOLE AND SOUTH CENTRAL VOLUSIA COUNTIES THROUGH 400 PM EDT

entry.title: Fire Weather Watch issued September 1 at 2:30PM CDT until September 2 at 8:00PM CDT by NWS Aberdeen SD
entry.summary:
The National Weather Service in Aberdeen has issued a Fire Weather Watch for wind and low relative humidity, which is in effect from Monday afternoon through Monday evening.
* AFFECTED AREA...In South Dakota, Corson, Dewey, Stanley and Jones.
* WINDS...South 20 to 25 mph with gusts up to 40 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...15 to 30 percent, with the lowest humidity across western portions of the affected counties.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that ignite will spread rapidly and become difficult to control or suppress, especially across portions of the affected counties where fuels are driest.

cap:parameter.value: FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT FROM MONDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH MONDAY EVENING FOR WIND AND LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY FOR CENTRAL SOUTH DAKOTA

IMPACT...Expect minor damage to tree limbs and blowing around of light, unsecured objects.

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued September 1 at 1:15PM MDT until September 2 at 10:00PM MDT by NWS Great Falls MT
entry.summary:
The National Weather Service in Great Falls has issued a Red Flag Warning for increasing thunderstorm activity, which is in effect from 2 PM to 10 PM MDT Monday. The Fire Weather Watch is no longer in effect.
* AFFECTED AREA...Helena and Townsend Ranger Districts of the Helena National Forest.
* WINDS...Southwest 5 to 10 mph, with gusts to 25 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 13 percent.
* TEMPERATURES...Up to 94.
* IMPACTS...The combination of low humidity and thunderstorm outflow winds may result in critical fire weather conditions, increasing the risk for new and existing fires to spread quickly.
* THUNDERSTORMS...The best chance for storms is from 2 PM until 10 PM Monday.
* OUTFLOW WINDS...Thunderstorm wind gusts near 50 mph at times.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Helena and Townsend Ranger Districts of the Helena National Forest

cap:parameter.value: RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT FROM 2 PM TO 10 PM MDT MONDAY FOR INCREASING THUNDERSTORM ACTIVITY FOR FIRE WEATHER ZONE 118

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued September 1 at 1:05PM MDT until September 1 at 8:00PM MDT by NWS Rapid City SD
entry.summary:
...RED FLAG WARNING FOR CAMPBELL COUNTY IN NORTHEAST WYOMING THIS AFTERNOON AND EVENING...
...RED FLAG WARNING FOR MUCH OF THE WESTERN SD PLAINS MONDAY AFTERNOON AND EVENING...
.Breezy south to southeast winds gusting to 35 mph, combined with relative humidities dropping to below 15 percent, and above average temperatures will support critical fire weather conditions over Campbell County this afternoon and early evening.
Strong southerly winds with gusts of over 40 mph with relative humidities ranging from 10 to 15 percent, combined with above average temperatures will support critical fire weather conditions over much of the western South Dakota plains Monday afternoon and evening.
* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zones 314 Northern Campbell and 315 Southern Campbell.
* WINDS...Southeast 15 to 20 mph with gusts up to 30 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 15 percent.
* IMPACTS...The combination of gusty winds and low relative humidity will produce critical fire weather conditions.

cap:parameter.value: RED FLAG WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 8 PM MDT THIS EVENING FOR GUSTY WINDS AND LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY FOR FIRE WEATHER ZONES 314 AND 315

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued September 1 at 1:05PM MDT until September 2 at 8:00PM MDT by NWS Rapid City SD
entry.summary:
...RED FLAG WARNING FOR CAMPBELL COUNTY IN NORTHEAST WYOMING THIS AFTERNOON AND EVENING...
...RED FLAG WARNING FOR MUCH OF THE WESTERN SD PLAINS MONDAY AFTERNOON AND EVENING...
.Breezy south to southeast winds gusting to 35 mph, combined with relative humidities dropping to below 15 percent, and above average temperatures will support critical fire weather conditions over Campbell County this afternoon and early evening.
Strong southerly winds with gusts of over 40 mph with relative humidities ranging from 10 to 15 percent, combined with above average temperatures will support critical fire weather conditions over much of the western South Dakota plains Monday afternoon and evening.
The National Weather Service in Rapid City has issued a Red Flag Warning for gusty winds and low relative humidity, which is in effect from noon MDT /1 PM CDT/ to 8 PM MDT /9 PM CDT/ Monday. The Fire Weather Watch is no longer in effect.
* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zones 322 Fall River County Area, 324 Eastern Foot Hills, 325 Custer County Plains, 326 Pine Ridge Area, 328 Perkins County, 329 West Central Plains, 330 Ziebach County, 331 Haakon County Area, 332 Badlands Area, 333 Bennett County Area and 334 Mellette and Todd Counties.
* WINDS...South 20 to 30 mph with gusts up to 45 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 10 percent.
* IMPACTS...The combination of gusty winds and low relative humidity will produce critical fire weather conditions.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Fall River County Area; Eastern Foot Hills; Custer County Plains; Pine Ridge Area; Perkins County; West Central Plains; Ziebach County; Haakon County Area; Badlands Area; Bennett County Area; Mellette and Todd Counties

cap:parameter.value: RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT FROM NOON MDT /1 PM CDT/ TO 8 PM MDT /9 PM CDT/ MONDAY FOR GUSTY WINDS AND LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY FOR FIRE WEATHER ZONES 322, 324, 325, 326, 328, 329, 330, 331, 332, 333, AND 334

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued September 1 at 2:05PM CDT until September 2 at 9:00PM CDT by NWS North Platte NE
entry.summary:
The National Weather Service in North Platte has issued a Red Flag Warning for wind and humidity, which is in effect from noon to 8 PM MDT Monday. A Fire Weather Watch has also been issued, which is in effect from Tuesday afternoon through Tuesday evening.
* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zone 204 Eastern Panhandle/Crescent Lake NWR.
* TIMING...For the Red Flag Warning, Monday afternoon and evening. For the Fire Weather Watch, Tuesday afternoon and evening.
* WINDS...South 15 to 25 mph with gusts up to 35 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 15 percent.
* TEMPERATURES...Highs around 90 on Monday. Highs in the lower to mid 90s on Tuesday.
* LIGHTNING...Not expected.
* IMPACTS...Any fire start will be capable of spreading rapidly and be difficult to control.

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued September 1 at 3:03PM EDT until September 1 at 4:30PM EDT by NWS Miami FL
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Urban and small stream flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...A portion of Southeast Palm Beach County near Boca Raton.
* WHEN...Until 430 PM EDT.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas. Ponding of water in urban or other areas is occurring or is imminent.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 301 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to thunderstorms. This will cause urban and small stream flooding. Between 2 and 3 inches of rain have fallen. - Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 3 inches are expected over the area. This additional rain will result in minor flooding. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Boca Raton, Highland Beach and Fau South Campus. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 430 PM EDT THIS AFTERNOON

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued September 1 at 3:02PM EDT until September 1 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Gaylord MI
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Dangerous swimming conditions are expected due to high wave action and strong rip currents.
* WHERE...Emmet, Leelanau, Antrim, Benzie, Manistee and Charlevoix Counties.
* WHEN...Until 8 PM EDT this evening.
* IMPACTS...Strong currents can pull swimmers into deeper water and high waves can sweep people off piers.

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued September 1 at 12:51PM MDT until September 2 at 10:00PM MDT by NWS Billings MT
entry.summary:
The National Weather Service in Billings has issued a Red Flag Warning...which is in effect from noon to 10 PM MDT Monday. The Fire Weather Watch is no longer in effect.
* IMPACTS: Low humidities, hot temperatures, gusty winds, and increasing thunderstorm activity may create erratic fire behavior and new fire starts.
* AFFECTED AREA: In South Central MT Fire Zone...123.
* COUNTIES AFFECTED: In South Central MT...Park...Sweet Grass. In Southwest MT...Gallatin.
* WIND: Southwest 10 to 15 mph with gusts to 25 mph.
* THUNDERSTORMS: A few high-based thunderstorms are possible in the late afternoon and evening. Any storms that develop have the potential to produce erratic wind gusts to 40 mph.
* HUMIDITY: From 10 to 18 percent.
* TEMPERATURES: Mid 70s at high elevations to the mid 90s in the valleys.

cap:parameter.value: RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT FROM NOON TO 10 PM MDT MONDAY

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued September 1 at 12:47PM MDT until September 3 at 12:00AM MDT by NWS Salt Lake City UT
entry.summary:
The National Weather Service in Salt Lake City has issued a Red Flag Warning for dry thunderstorms and gusty outflow winds, which is in effect from 3 PM Monday to midnight MDT Monday night.
* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zone 478 Salt Lake Desert and Fire Weather Zone 492 Central Utah West Desert.
* IMPACTS...New lightning starts are possible. Gusty outflow winds could bring rapid growth of new or existing fires.
* THUNDERSTORMS...Widely scattered dry thunderstorms.
* OUTFLOW WINDS...35 to 45 mph.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Salt Lake Desert; Central Utah West Desert

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued September 1 at 2:12PM AST until September 1 at 6:00PM AST by NWS San Juan PR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...Aguada, Anasco, Las Marias, Maricao, Mayaguez, Moca, Rincon and San Sebastian.
* WHEN...Until 600 PM AST.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas. Rises in small streams and normally dry arroyos. Water over roadways. Overflowing poor drainage areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 208 PM AST, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to thunderstorms. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly in the advisory area. Between 0.5 and 1.5 inches of rain have fallen. - Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches are expected over the area. This additional rain will result in minor flooding. - This thunderstorm is now located between Maricao and Anasco, and will continue to move west-northwest into neighboring municipalities. Additional thunderstorm development is expected over the area within the advisory time. For this reason, the Flood Advisory has been issued through 6 PM AST. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Aguada, PR; Anasco, PR; Las Marias, PR; Maricao, PR; Mayaguez, PR; Moca, PR; Rincon, PR; San Sebastian, PR

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 PM AST THIS EVENING

entry.title: Flood Watch issued September 1 at 12:44PM CDT until September 3 at 7:00PM CDT by NWS San Angelo TX
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is possible.
* WHERE...A portion of west central Texas, including the following counties, Brown, Callahan, Coke, Coleman, Concho, Crockett, Irion, Kimble, Mason, McCulloch, Menard, Nolan, Runnels, San Saba, Schleicher, Sterling, Sutton, Taylor and Tom Green.
* WHEN...From Monday morning through Tuesday evening.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Flooding may occur in poor drainage and urban areas. Low-water crossings may be flooded.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Showers and thunderstorms will become widespread Monday into Tuesday, with multiple rounds of heavy rainfall possible. The heavy rain may result in flooding of roadways, low water crossings, creeks, and rivers. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Nolan; Sterling; Coke; Runnels; Irion; Tom Green; Concho; Crockett; Schleicher; Sutton; Taylor; Callahan; Coleman; Brown; McCulloch; San Saba; Menard; Kimble; Mason

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WATCH IN EFFECT FROM MONDAY MORNING THROUGH TUESDAY EVENING

Between 0.5 and 0.75 inches of rain have fallen. - Additional rainfall amounts of 0.5 to 1 inch are expected over the area. This additional rain will result in minor flooding. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Menard, Paint Rock, Eden, Millersview, Live Oak, Us-83 Near The Menard-Concho County Line, The Intersection Of Us-87 And Ranch Road 2134, The Intersection Of Us-83 And Highway 29, The Intersection Of Us-83 And Ranch Road 765 and Camp Sol Mayer. - This includes the following Low Water Crossings... Decker St. crossing San Saba River, crossings along County Road 4071, crossings along County Road 3077, County Road 3034 crossing Brady Creek, crossings along County Road 3071, County Road 3071 crossing Brady Creek, crossings along County Road 3059, County Road 3053 crossing Brady Creek, County Road 4131 crossing Maverick Creek and County Road 2019 crossing Brady Creek. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Fire Weather Watch issued September 1 at 8:25AM MDT until September 2 at 9:00PM MDT by NWS Boise ID
entry.summary:
...FIRE WEATHER WATCH NOW IN EFFECT MONDAY MORNING INTO MONDAY EVENING FOR A COMBINATION OF LIGHTNING AND WIND/RH FOR FIRE WEATHER ZONES 636 AND 637...
...FIRE WEATHER WATCH NOW IN EFFECT FROM MONDAY MORNING THROUGH MONDAY EVENING FOR LIGHTNING FOR FIRE WEATHER ZONES 400, 401, 402, 403, 420, 421, 423, 424, 426, AND 646...
.An upper level system will bring two rounds of showers and thunderstorms with the potential for scattered lightning to the region from Monday morning through Monday evening. Isolated storms will also be seen this afternoon/evening (before the watch takes effect) south of the Snake River in Idaho and in SE Oregon. All these storms will have gusts potential to 50 mph.
* Thunderstorms...Scattered storms likely.
* Outflow Winds...50 mph.
* Timing...From Monday morning through Monday evening.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued September 1 at 8:53AM CDT by NWS Brownsville TX
entry.summary:
The combination of above normal high temperatures and relative humidity percentages will result in uncomfortably hot conditions across Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley today. Heat index values are expected to range between 105 and 110 degrees for a few hours this afternoon. Isolated areas may briefly experience heat indices up to 111 degrees for a short period of time.
If working outside today, be sure to drink plenty of water, wear loose-fitting and light-colored clothing, and take frequent breaks in air-conditioned locations. Be sure to check on elderly and infirm neighbors and relatives, provide shade and fresh water for outdoor pets and livestock, and check the backseat of your vehicle when transporting children.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Brooks; Inland Kenedy; Starr; Southern Hidalgo; Inland Willacy; Inland Cameron; Coastal Kenedy; Northern Hidalgo; Coastal Willacy; Coastal Cameron

entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
Myakka River At Myakka River State Park affecting Sarasota County.
For the Myakka...including Myakka River State Park...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Myakka River at Myakka River State Park.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 8.0 feet, The main road at Myakka State Park floods.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 9:00 AM EDT Sunday the stage was 7.8 feet. - Bankfull stage is 7.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 9:00 AM EDT Sunday was 7.8 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to remain steady above flood stage at 7.8 feet. - Flood stage is 7.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 8.0 feet on 10/11/1995. - https://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Warning issued September 1 at 9:36AM EDT until September 6 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Jacksonville FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
Santa Fe River At Three Rivers Estates affecting Columbia, Gilchrist and Suwannee Counties.
Additional information is available at https://water.weather.gov/wfo/JAX
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Santa Fe River at Three Rivers Estates.
* WHEN...Until Friday evening.
* IMPACTS...At 16.0 feet, Lowland flooding begins on SW Santa Fe Drive south of Santa Fe Road in Columbia County. At 16.3 feet, Florida Fish and Wildlife Commission begins enforcement of a no wake zone on the Santa Fe River from the unnamed island 1.5 miles downstream of the Wilson's Spring Boat Ramp to the confluence with the Suwannee River and on the Ichetucknee River upstream to the US 27 bridge. At 17.0 feet, Water begins to enter backyards of residences on Santa Fe Road in Columbia County and on River Run Road in Suwannee County. At 18.0 feet, Water begins to flood River Run Road in Suwannee County. At 18.8 feet, Florida Fish and Wildlife Commission expands the no wake zone restriction further upstream on the Santa Fe River from the unnamed island 1.5 miles downstream on the Wilson's Spring Boat Ramp to one-half mile upstream of the State Road 47 bridge. At 19.0 feet, Water begins to enter backyards of residences along the Ichetucknee River. At 19.8 feet, Waters begins to affect homes in the Hollingsworth Bluff area at State Route 47. At 20.0 feet, Access to homes on Santa Fe Road below SW Riverside Avenue becomes restricted in Columbia. Flooding begins on Santa Fe and Wilson Springs Road.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 9:00 AM EDT Sunday the stage was 18.5 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage early Saturday morning and continue falling to 16.5 feet Sunday, September 08. - Flood stage is 17.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Columbia, FL; Gilchrist, FL; Suwannee, FL

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FRIDAY EVENING

entry.summary:

* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 15-20 percent.
* TEMPERATURES...Up to 85.
* HAINES...Mid-level Haines 6.

entry.title: Excessive Heat Watch issued September 1 at 2:27AM PDT until September 6 at 9:00PM PDT by NWS Los Angeles/Oxnard CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Dangerously hot conditions with high temperatures of 105 to 110 possible. Warm overnight low temperatures in the lower to middle 70s will bring little relief from the heat.
* WHERE...Western San Fernando Valley.
* WHEN...From Tuesday morning through Friday evening.
* IMPACTS...There is a high risk for dangerous heat illness for anyone, especially for the very young, the very old, those without air conditioning, and those active outdoors.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...There is a small chance, 20 percent, for temperatures to reach upwards of 115 degrees or even locally higher on Thursday. This has the potential to be a very dangerous heatwave for the Western San Fernando Valley. Additional heat headlines will likely be issued elsewhere across the region for latter parts of the week in subsequent forecasts.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued September 1 at 1:19AM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
A low pressure system will develop in the Western Bering Sea which will impact Saint Lawrence Island, Bering Strait and the Chukchi Sea Coast, as well as the Western North Slope Monday into Wednesday. South-Southwestly winds will begin to increase on Monday and becoming more Southerly on Tuesday. Gale force winds possible, as well as elevated wave swells offshore. Heavy rain showers expected for Northwest Alaska on Monday. Winds will begin to diminish some by Wednesday evening.
Stay tuned to the latest forecast updates at www.weather.gov/afg
entry.cap:areaDesc: Western Arctic Coast; Northwest Arctic Coast

cap:parameter.value: Winds and Elevated Water levels for the Western North Slope Monday into Wednesday

entry.cap:areaDesc: Kivalina and Red Dog Dock; Baldwin Peninsula; Shishmaref; Bering Strait Coast; Southern Seward Peninsula Coast; Eastern Norton Sound and Nulato Hills; Yukon Delta Coast; St Lawrence Island

entry.summary:
...FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT FROM MONDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH MONDAY EVENING FOR SCATTERED THUNDERSTORMS FOR FIRE WEATHER ZONES 410, 411, 413, 422, 425, 427, 475, AND 476...
* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zone 410 Upper Snake River Valley/Idaho Falls BLM, Fire Weather Zone 411 Centennial Mountains and Snake River Range/Targhee NF, Fire Weather Zone 413 Caribou Range/Caribou NF, Fire Weather Zone 422 Sawtooth Range/Northern Sawtooth NF, Fire Weather Zone 425 Middle Snake River Valley/Twin Falls BLM north of the Snake River, Fire Weather Zone 427 Goose Creek and Raft River Valley/Southern Sawtooth NF/Twin Falls BLM south of the Snake River, Fire Weather Zone 475 East Salmon River Mountains/Salmon NF and Fire Weather Zone 476 Lemhi and Lost River Range/Challis NF.
* IMPACTS...New lightning starts are possible, with gusty outflow winds possibly leading to rapid growth of new or existing fires.
* THUNDERSTORMS...Scattered dry thunderstorms.
* OUTFLOW WINDS...35 to 45 mph.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Upper Snake River Valley/Idaho Falls BLM; Centennial Mountains and Snake River Range/Targhee NF; Caribou Range/Caribou NF; Sawtooth Range/Northern Sawtooth NF; Middle Snake River Valley/Twin Falls BLM north of the Snake River; Goose Creek and Raft River Valley/Southern Sawtooth NF/Twin Falls BLM south of the Snake River; East Salmon River Mountains/Salmon NF; Lemhi and Lost River Range/Challis NF

cap:parameter.value: FIRE WEATHER WATCH REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM MONDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH MONDAY EVENING FOR SCATTERED THUNDERSTORMS FOR FIRE WEATHER ZONES 410, 411, 413, 422, 425, 427, 475, AND 476

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued September 1 at 3:29AM EDT until September 1 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Marquette MI
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Dangerous swimming conditions are expected due to high wave action and strong rip currents.
* WHERE...Marquette and Alger Counties.
* WHEN...From 8 AM EDT this morning through this evening.
* IMPACTS...High wave action and dangerous currents will lead to life threatening swimming conditions. Waves in rapid succession can tire swimmers quickly.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Current related fatalities and rescues in the past have occurred due to similar wave conditions at locations listed below:
For Marquette County: Middle Bay north of Presque Isle and at Little Presque Isle.
For Alger County: The Au Train River mouth at Au Train, the exposed regions of Grand Marais Harbor, and Pictured Rocks National Lakeshore.

cap:parameter.value: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT IN EFFECT FROM 8 AM EDT THIS MORNING THROUGH THIS EVENING

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued September 1 at 3:19AM EDT until September 1 at 10:00PM EDT by NWS Detroit/Pontiac MI
entry.summary:
* WHAT...High swim risk from high wave action and strong currents on Saginaw Bay and Lake Huron. Dangerous swimming conditions expected.
* WHERE...Huron County.
* WHEN...From 8 AM EDT this morning through this evening.
* IMPACTS...Strong currents can pull swimmers into deep water and prevent return to shore.

cap:parameter.value: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM 8 AM EDT THIS MORNING THROUGH THIS EVENING

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 31 at 4:00PM MDT by NWS Great Falls MT
entry.summary:
AQAMT
The Montana Department of Environmental Quality has issued an air quality alert for Beaverhead and Ravalli counties in effect until 4PM 9/1/2024 elevated particulate levels from wildfire smoke This alert will be updated again at 400pm 9/1/2024.
An Air Quality Alert means that particulates have been trending upwards and that an exceedence of the 24 hour National Ambient Air Quality Standard (NAAQS) has occurred or may occur in the near future.
As of 4PM, Particulate levels in Hamilton are Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups
As of 4PM, Particulate levels in Dillon are Moderate
When air quality is Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups... State and local health officials recommend that people with respiratory or heart disease, the elderly and children should limit prolonged exertion.
When air quality is Moderate... State and local health officials recommend that unusually sensitive people should consider reducing prolonged or heavy exertion.
For more information visit the Montana Department of Environmental Quality at http://todaysair.mtdeq.us

entry.title: Fire Weather Watch issued August 31 at 1:20PM MDT until September 2 at 8:00PM MDT by NWS Cheyenne WY
entry.summary:
...FIRE WEATHER WATCH FOR THE NEBRASKA PANHANDLE AND PARTS OF EXTREME SOUTHEAST WYOMING MONDAY FOR GUSTY WINDS AND LOW HUMIDITY...
The National Weather Service in Cheyenne has issued a Fire Weather Watch, which is in effect from Monday afternoon through Monday evening.
* AFFECTED AREA...Fire weather zone 433 through 437...417 and 431.
* WIND...South to southeast winds 20 to 25 mph sustained with gusts of 30 to 35 mph.
* HUMIDITY...Afternoon humidity 7 to 15 percent.
* IMPACTS...any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Pine Ridge/Nebraska National Forest; Box Butte/South Sioux/Niobrara River; Lower North Platte River Basin/Scottsbluff National Monument; Lodgepole Creek/Southern Nebraska Panhandle; Niobrara/Lower Elevations of Converse/Thunder Basin National Grassland; Laramie East High Plains; Goshen/Middle-Lower North Platte River Basin

entry.title: The Fire Weather Watch has been cancelled.
entry.summary: The Fire Weather Watch has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 30 at 12:44PM MDT by NWS Boise ID
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Air Quality Advisory because of degraded air quality due to wildfire smoke.
Air Quality Index is forecast to be Unhealthy.
* WHERE...Camas, Gooding, Jerome, and Twin Falls Counties.
* WHEN...UNTIL 2 PM MDT SUNDAY.
* IMPACTS...Everyone may begin to experience health effects; members of sensitive groups may experience more serious health effects.
